qas.question: How many independent labels did the Merlin Network represent?
What was the percentage of labels youtube had signed contracts with prior to the planned launch date?
What was youtube planning on doing to labels it did not reach a deal with?
Why did youtube want to ensure only contractees music was played?

answers.text: to launch the enhanced music experience

qas.question: Which journalistic organization released the reports of youtube's agreement with the Merlin Network?
What service launched in May 2014 was a subscription based service?

plausible_answers.text: YouTube would block the content of labels who do not negotiate deals to be included in the paid service

qas.question: What did Robert Kyncl confirm in May 2014?

plausible_answers.text: "to ensure that all content on the platform is governed by its new contractual terms

qas.question: What reason did Robert Kyncl give in May 2014 for YouTube blocking content labels?
What did Kyncl say 100% of the labels had reached?

context: In May 2014, prior to the launch of YouTube's subscription-based <b5_0>Music Key<b5_0/> service, the independent music trade organization Worldwide Independent Network alleged that YouTube was using non-negotiable contracts with independent labels that were "undervalued" in comparison to other streaming services, and that YouTube would <a2_0>block all music content<a2_0/> from labels who do not reach a deal to be included on the paid service. In a statement to the Financial Times in June 2014, Robert Kyncl confirmed that <b6_0>YouTube would block the content of labels who do not negotiate deals to be included in the paid service<b6_0/> <b7_0>"to ensure that all content on the platform is governed by its new contractual terms<b7_0/>." Stating that <a1_0>90%<a1_0/> of labels had reached <b8_0>deals<b8_0/>, he went on to say that "while we wish that we had [a] 100% success rate, we understand that is not likely an achievable goal and therefore it is our responsibility to our users and the industry <a3_0>to launch the enhanced music experience<a3_0/>." <a4_0>The Financial Times<a4_0/> later reported that YouTube had reached an aggregate deal with Merlin Network—a trade group representing over <a0_0>20,000<a0_0/> independent labels, for their inclusion in the service. However, YouTube itself has not confirmed the deal.
